item.title: Iran’s Supreme Leader Condemns Mob Attack on Saudi Embassy
item.description: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei said the assault that followed the execution of a Shiite cleric in Saudi Arabia was “detrimental to the country and Islam.”
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: A demonstration in Tehran this month after the execution of a prominent Shiite cleric in Saudi Arabia.

item.title: Sinosphere: Database Tracks ‘Tigers and Flies’ Caught in Xi Jinping’s Corruption Crackdown
item.description: ChinaFile has compiled an online visual database of all the corruption cases that have ensnared senior and low-ranking officials since Mr. Xi took power.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Squabbles Persist Over Who Should Be at Syria Peace Talks
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry and the Russian foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, met to discuss disputes over the talks, which are scheduled to begin Monday.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry and Foreign Minister Sergey V. Lavrov of Russia met in Zurich on Wednesday to talk about Syria.

item.title: World Briefing: Nepal Police Fire on Madhesi Protesters, Killing at Least 3
item.description: Members of the Madhesi group have been demanding changes to Nepal’s new Constitution, which they say dilutes their political voice.
item.dc:creator: BHADRA SHARMA

item.title: Letter From Europe: The Past Haunts Oxford Debate Over Rhodes Statue
item.description: Is the campaign to remove the statue about unhealed colonial wounds or fear among Westerners that their version of history may be sacrificed?
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: A statue of the colonialist Cecil John Rhodes on the facade of Oriel College in Oxford, England.

item.title: Zika Virus May be Linked to Surge in Rare Syndrome in Brazil
item.description: Brazilian officials said that Zika, a virus linked to brain damage in infants, may be causing an increase in the number of cases of Guillain-Barré, an autoimmune condition.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO and DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.
item.media:description: Soldiers and a public health official checked a residence for signs of the Aedes aegypti mosquito, which transmits the Zika virus, in São Paulo, Brazil, on Wednesday.

item.title: Vibrant Lives of Afghan TV Crew, Erased in a Taliban Bombing
item.description: When a Taliban suicide bomber blew up a bus in Kabul this week, it ended the lives of seven employees of Tolo TV — the intended target.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Italy’s Famed Palio Horsemen Decline Royal Invitation
item.description: Queen Elizabeth II’s birthday celebrations in May will not feature representatives of the Palio race in Tuscany, who said their request for certain conditions was not met.
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI
item.media:description: The Palio di Siena race in 2012. City officials declined an invitation to join a parade at Windsor Castle for Queen Elizabeth II’s 90th birthday celebrations.

item.title: Giving Voice to France’s Poorest Youth, With Rhymes and Beats
item.description: After the Paris terrorist attacks, hip-hop artists are clashing perhaps more than ever with the country’s expanding and vituperative far right.
item.dc:creator: SUZANNE DALEY
item.media:credit: Pierre Terdjman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The rapper Médine in his neighborhood in Le Havre, France.

item.title: Catholic Church’s Hold on Schools at Issue in Changing Ireland
item.description: Almost all state-funded primary schools are under church control, and Irish law allows them to consider religion the main factor in admissions.
item.category: United Nations Committee on the Rights of the Child
item.dc:creator: DOUGLAS DALBY
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nikki Murphy with her 4-year-old son, Reuben, at their home in Dublin. Reuben was refused entry into nine schools because he was not baptized by a Catholic church.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Aung San Suu Kyi, the Dragon's Lady
item.description: China’s courtship of the National League for Democracy is unnerving Myanmar’s generals.
item.dc:creator: MIN ZIN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Building the Future in Israel
item.description: The Jewish state is most secure when its Arab citizens share in the promise of prosperity.
item.dc:creator: YOAV GALLANT

item.title: Memo From China: China Uses Foreigners’ Televised Confessions to Serve Its Own Ends
item.description: A Swedish man’s confession on state television is the latest case of China broadcasting self-criticism as propaganda for an audience of hundreds of millions.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.media:credit: China Central Television, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A still image of Peter Dahlin, a Swedish co-founder of a human rights group, taken from a video shown on China Central Television on Tuesday night.

item.title: Q. and A.: Assessing the Road to the Syrian Peace Talks
item.description: A look at the hurdles and the possibilities related to the negotiations diplomats hope to begin on Monday.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Putin ‘Probably Approved’ Litvinenko Poisoning, British Inquiry Says
item.description: The finding represented by far the most damning official link between the 2006 death of Alexander V. Litvinenko, an ex-K.G.B. officer, and the highest levels of the Kremlin.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Alexander V. Litvinenko at a London hospital in 2006, shortly before he died from ingesting green tea laced with polonium 210.

item.title: Draft of Inquiry Report on Jimmy Savile Cites Flaws in BBC Culture
item.description: The 500-page document, published by the news website Exaro, said the inquiry had heard from many employees who knew of Mr. Savile’s predatory behavior.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA
item.media:credit: Les Lee/Hulton Archive, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Jimmy Savile after being appointed an officer of the Most Excellent Order of the British Empire at Buckingham Palace in London, in 1972.

item.title: As Amir Hekmati Sat in an Iranian Prison, Michigan Supporters Kept His Name in the News
item.description: While Mr. Hekmati did not know about the level of support for him, Representative Dan Kildee said, Iranian government officials were constantly made aware of it.
item.dc:creator: SCOTT ATKINSON
item.media:description: Amir Hekmati, a Marine veteran from Flint, Mich., in a photo provided by his family.

item.title: World Briefing: Tunisia: Protesters Demand Jobs
item.description: For a second day, the police clashed with protesters demanding jobs in Kasserine, and one officer was killed in Feriana as demonstrations broke out in other cities and towns.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Singapore: Bangladeshis Expelled
item.description: Singapore said it had deported 26 construction workers for forming a religious study group that spread the ideology of Al Qaeda and the Islamic State group.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Massacre Came as Pakistan University Honored a Hero of Nonviolence
item.description: At least 20 people were killed amid preparations for a poetry recital in honor of Abdul Ghaffar Khan, a peaceful Pashtun leader for whom the school was named.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK
item.media:credit: Universal History Archive/Universal Images Group, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Mahatma Gandhi, left, and Abdul Ghaffar Khan, center, in 1939. At least 20 people were killed on Wednesday, the 28th anniversary of Mr. Ghaffar Khan’s death, at a university in Pakistan that bears his nickname, Bacha Khan.
